headline.main: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 225th Session

byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

docs.abstract: Summary of actions taken by 225th annual session of New York State Legislature; bills enacted, and legislation that failed, in areas of budget, crime and justice, business and labor, consumer affairs, taxes, environment and energy, education, health care, transportation and government and elections noted; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: The 225th annual session of the New York State Legislature dragged quietly to a tentative close on July 2, after six months of partisan posturing and wrangling and very little real action. Time and again, Gov. George E. Pataki, the Republicans who control the Senate and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly appeared to make progress toward major deals, only to see them fall apart in waves of recrimination. It was, by all accounts, one of the most gridlocked years in memory, a sharp departure from the axiom that Albany finds a way to do business in even-numbered years, when officials must stand for re-election.

docs.abstract: Editorial calls for much more research on health problems of Hispanic children
docs.lead_paragraph: One in every six American children is Hispanic, but it's hard to find them in the research on child health. According to the Journal of the American Medical Association, Latino children suffer from a disproportionate number of health problems that have been poorly studied. Diabetes is on the rise, and Latino boys have the highest rates of obesity among young people, but researchers don't know why. They also don't know why Puerto Rican children have rates of asthma higher than those in any other region. Many of the statistics pose mysteries that go beyond the fact that Hispanic children are less likely to be covered by health insurance than are children in other ethnic groups. For instance, Latino children who are hospitalized with limb fractures receive less pain medication than do white or African-American youths. No one seems to know why, and data is hard to collect because Hispanic children are often included in the categories of white, black or ''other'' in medical research. Many researchers also ignore these children and their parents by excluding non-English-speakers from their studies.
